channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Anthony B. Atkinson, Economist Who Pioneered Study of Inequality, Dies at 72
item.media:description: Anthony B. Atkinson was known for his creative and exacting use of empirical methods, but also proposed bold policy ideas, like creating a “minimum inheritance” to be distributed on reaching adulthood.
item.media:credit: David Ausserhofer/ullstein bild, via Getty Images
item.description: Mr. Atkinson developed new ways to measure disparities in income and wealth using historical records, long before inequality became the major issue it is today.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: German ISIS Member Who Denied Killing Is Charged in Murders
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, an imprisoned Islamic State member from Germany, attracted global attention after claiming disillusionment and disgust with the terrorist group.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: New accusations by German prosecutors against the prisoner, Harry Sarfo, came three months after a video appeared to incriminate him in a mass killing.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Coal Fire, Not Just Iceberg, Doomed the Titanic, a Journalist Claims
item.media:description: The Titanic leaving Southampton, England, on its ill-fated voyage on April 10, 1912.
item.media:credit: Southampton City Council, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A documentary posits that the demise of the ship may have been accelerated by a giant blaze in its hull that appeared to have started as long as three weeks before it set off.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Suicide Bombing in Baghdad Kills at Least 36
item.media:description: The remains of a suicide car bombing on Monday in a bustling outdoor market in Baghdad’s eastern Sadr City district.
item.description: The Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attack in a produce market on Monday that wounded at least 52 others.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Benjamin Netanyahu Questioned in Israel Graft Inquiry
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday. “This will all come to nothing, because there is nothing,” he has said repeatedly of recent accusations of impropriety against him.
item.description: Police investigators questioned the prime minister for three hours at his official residence on suspicion of receiving illicit gifts and favors from business executives.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: India’s Call-Center Talents Put to a Criminal Use: Swindling Americans
item.media:description: Pawan Poojary, 18, left, and Jayesh Dubey, 19, were part of a scheme targeting Americans run from a call center in Thane, a suburb of Mumbai, India.
item.media:credit: Poras Chaudhary for The New York Times
item.description: The availability of computer-savvy, young, English-speaking job seekers and efficient technology have contributed to the growth in cyberfraud against Americans.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: As Scandal Roils South Korea, Fingers Point to Mixing of Politics and Business
item.media:description: A supporter of South Korea’s president, Park Geun-hye, in Seoul last month. A scandal has focused public scrutiny on the power of the presidency and its symbiotic relationship with family-controlled conglomerates like Samsung.
item.description: Outrage over President Park Geun-hye’s actions has turned to broader concerns over the power of the presidency and its relationship with conglomerates.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN and MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Indian Official Blames Women’s Western Dress for Sexual Harassment
item.media:description: Police officers at New Year’s Eve celebrations in Bangalore, India, where numerous women reported being groped and harassed.
item.description: An unruly crowd on New Year’s Eve in Bangalore again brought sexual assault and street safety to the fore, with some politicians faulting the victims rather than the assailants.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Pact Would Force Out Joseph Kabila From Congo. If, of Course, He Agrees.
item.media:description: Congolese Catholic bishops before mediating talks between the opposition and the government of President Joseph Kabila of Congo in Kinshasa in December.
item.description: In an agreement announced by a group of bishops, the president would step down and elections would be held. But Mr. Kabila has not yet agreed to the deal.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Airline Pilot, Believed to Be Drunk, Is Pulled From Cockpit in Canada
item.description: A Sunwing Airlines pilot was charged with alcohol-related offenses after being found passed out in the captain’s chair while the plane was on the tarmac, the police said.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: What in the World: What a Tangled Web We Weave
item.description: Where safety regulations on power lines and other wires are lax, things can get pretty out of hand. One magazine sought to illustrate just how much.
item.dc:creator: SETH MYDANS

item.title: In Blow to ‘Brexit’ Plans, Britain’s Top Envoy to E.U. Resigns
item.media:description: Many analysts had expected Ivan Rogers to use his expertise to play a leading role in the complex negotiations of Britain’s exit from the European Union.
item.description: The British government said Ivan Rogers was leaving early to give his successor a chance to take over before formal exit negotiations start.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Germany’s Latest Best Seller? A Critical Version of ‘Mein Kampf’
item.media:description: “Hitler, Mein Kampf, A Critical Edition,” includes about 3,500 annotations by a team of scholars and historians.
item.description: Historians say their annotated edition of Hitler’s manifesto has provoked a necessary discussion and sold 85,000 copies one year since publication
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Park Geun-hye, South Korean President, Is a No-Show at Impeachment Trial
item.media:description: Formal hearings in President Park Geun-hye’s impeachment trial began on Tuesday at South Korea’s Constitutional Court in Seoul.
item.description: Lawyers for Ms. Park said she was unlikely to attend any of the proceedings at the Constitutional Court, which will decide whether she is removed from office.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Lecce Journal: Italian Inmates Sip, Smell and Taste Their Way to Rehabilitation
item.media:description: The sommelier Roberto Giannone poured wine for inmates near Lecce, Italy, as Marco Albanese, a police officer and wine enthusiast, gave a class on tasting and serving.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: A program teaches prisoners new professional skills and helps them develop a bond with the region known for its Negroamaro grape varieties.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Sinosphere: Time-Lapse Video Shows Beijing Swamped by a Tide of Smog
item.description: The pollution in Beijing has been particularly bad recently, and the city has been enveloped in smog for extended periods starting in October.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY

item.title: Myanmar Holds Officers After Video Purports to Show Police Beating Rohingya
item.media:description: Myanmar’s de facto leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
item.description: The recording, which appears to depict unarmed members of the Rohingya minority being beaten in Rakhine State, adds to pressure on the government.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: France Lets Workers Turn Off, Tune Out and Live Life
item.description: A raft of measures meant to balance modernity and tradition will make it easier to unplug from work email, protect the environment and get divorced.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: ‘It Won’t Happen,’ Donald Trump Says of North Korean Missile Test
item.description: Mr. Trump takes office in less than three weeks, and a successful long-range-missile test would present one of his first big national security tests.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Hilarion Capucci, Archbishop Jailed for Aiding Palestinian Militants, Dies at 94
item.media:description: Archbishop Hilarion Capucci in 2009 with activists opposing Israel’s blockade of the Gaza Strip.
item.description: As the head of the Greek Catholic Church in Jerusalem, he was charged with smuggling arms to help Palestinians. The Vatican helped secure his release.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Cardinal Calls It a ‘Disgrace,’ but a McDonald’s Opens Near the Vatican
item.description: Residents and Roman Catholic leaders say the restaurant clashes with the aesthetics of the area, but an agency of the Vatican itself is the landlord.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Joyce Appleby, Historian of Capitalism and American Identity, Is Dead at 87
item.media:description: Joyce Appleby.
item.description: She put liberalism at the center of understanding the ideology of the revolutionary generation.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: India’s Top Court Bars Campaigns Based on Identity Politics
item.media:description: Posters of Hindu gods in Guwahati, India, on Monday. The top court in the country said that the Constitution enshrines its elections as fundamentally secular.
item.description: The ruling, which restricts appeals to voters by religion, caste, community or language, is meant to ensure that elections are secular.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Riot by Drug Gangs in Brazil Prison Leaves at Least 56 Dead
item.description: The authorities said the riot at the Compaj prison in Manaus was part of a power struggle over the drug trade in the Amazon basin.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Yadua Island Journal: On a Fijian Island, Hunters Become Conservators of Endangered Turtles
item.media:description: Pita Qarau catching a hawksbill turtle to monitor its health on the Fijian island of Yadua in November.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: A moratorium on harvesting turtles and a World Wildlife Fund program have helped replenish Fiji’s turtle population after decades of decline.
item.dc:creator: SERENA SOLOMON
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature

item.title: Sinosphere: Transgender Man Was Unfairly Fired, but Bias Not Proved, Chinese Court Says
item.media:description: Mr. C holding a receipt last March for the complaint he filed with a labor arbitration committee in Guiyang, in the southwestern Chinese province of Guizhou, attributing his firing to bias against transgender individuals.
item.description: The court ordered the company to pay the plaintiff, identified as Mr. C, 2,000 renminbi in compensation but did not grant his demand for an apology.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO

item.title: Daughter of Key Figure in South Korean Scandal Is Detained in Denmark
item.media:description: Chung Yoo-ra, center, with her equestrian team members in South Korea in 2014. Ms. Chung is the daughter of Choi Soon-sil, the longtime confidante of President Park Geun-hye who is at the center of the scandal.
item.description: South Korean officials will seek the extradition of the daughter of Choi Soon-sil, the presidential confidante at the center of an influence-peddling scandal.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Fecal Pollution Taints Water at Melbourne’s Beaches After Storm
item.description: During the height of Australia’s summer, the authorities have advised against swimming at 21 beaches because of contamination brought in by heavy rains.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: Global Health: Easing the Toll of Sickle Cell Disease in Childbirth
item.media:description: Sickle cell anemia in human blood.
item.description: Creating teams at a hospital in Ghana to treat pregnant women who have the disease reduced their death rates by almost 90 percent.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Istanbul Nightclub Attack
item.media:description: The funeral in Istanbul on Monday of another victim, 23-year-old Yunus Gormek.
item.description: The authorities are still searching for the gunman who killed at least 39 people at the upscale Reina nightclub.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: News Analysis: In Banning Ivory Trade, China Saw Benefits for Itself, Too
item.media:description: Confiscated ivory in Zhuhai, China, last year. The ban reinforced President Xi Jinping’s campaign against corrupt officials, who frequently use ivory products as bribes.
item.description: The decision to bring the world’s largest ivory market to a halt by the end of 2017 lets China burnish its image as a global guardian of the environment.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
